global_notes: Three baseline groups match the surface exactly. G1 covers cement floor coverage (housing first stage, household-level data). G2 covers maternal mental health and life satisfaction (household-level data). G3 covers child health outcomes (individual-level data, children 0-5). All baseline groups have treatment_var=dpisofirme, inference=infer/se/cluster/idcluster. No adjustments made to baseline group assignments from the surface. G2 and G3 run rc/* rows across all outcome variants simultaneously (not just the primary baseline outcome), which is correct practice for a multi-outcome claim group. Trim rows produce identical coefficients to baseline for share/binary outcomes (S_shcementfloor, S_satisfloor, S_diarrhea) because these bounded outcomes have no extremal outliers; this is a real empirical finding, not a coding error. G3 rc/controls/loo/drop_S_age and rc/controls/loo/drop_S_gender produce identical coefficients to rc/controls/sets/model4 (n_controls differs: 89 vs 91), suggesting S_age and S_gender do not move the treatment coefficient; plausible for a randomized experiment with balanced baseline characteristics. Inference variants (infer/se/hc/hc1, infer/se/cluster/idmun) correctly appear only in inference_results.csv. Gap in spec_run_id sequence (runs 036-037, 068, and 099 are in inference_results.csv) is expected.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: ITT of Piso Firme cement floor program on share of rooms with cement floors (housing quality first stage), households in Torreon vs Durango (2005)
baseline_groups.outcome_concept: Share of rooms with cement floors (S_shcementfloor)
baseline_groups.target_population: Households in poor neighborhoods of Torreon and Durango (N=2755)
baseline_groups.expected_sign_rationale: Program provides cement floors; direct first-stage effect expected strongly positive.
baseline_groups.notes: Four baseline specs: no-controls (m1/baseline), partial controls (m2,m3), full controls (m4). All produce near-identical coefficients (0.2019-0.2103) and p~0, confirming strong first-stage. design/diff_in_means matches baseline exactly (no controls, same estimator). rc/controls/subset random_001..010 also included (G1 only had budget for 10 subsets).

baseline_groups.claim_summary: ITT of Piso Firme on maternal mental health and life satisfaction (S_satisfloor, S_satishouse, S_satislife, S_cesds, S_pss), households in Torreon vs Durango (2005)
baseline_groups.outcome_concept: Maternal mental health and life satisfaction (multiple outcomes)
baseline_groups.estimand_concept: ITT on satisfaction and mental health measures
baseline_groups.target_population: Households in poor neighborhoods of Torreon and Durango (N=2742-2755)
baseline_groups.expected_sign: positive for satisfaction (S_satisfloor, S_satishouse, S_satislife); negative for distress (S_cesds, S_pss)
baseline_groups.expected_sign_rationale: Cement floors improve housing conditions, expected to raise satisfaction and reduce stress/depression.
baseline_groups.notes: Five baseline outcomes: S_satisfloor (primary, floor satisfaction), S_satishouse, S_satislife, S_cesds (depression scale, negative), S_pss (stress scale, negative). rc/controls/sets rows run across all 5 outcomes simultaneously. rc/controls/loo and rc/sample rows applied only to S_satisfloor (primary) and S_cesds (stress). All estimates statistically significant at 5% or better. No inference variants in specification_results.csv; infer/se/hc/hc1 correctly in inference_results.csv.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: ITT of Piso Firme on child health outcomes (S_parcount, S_diarrhea, S_anemia, S_haz, S_whz), children 0-5 in Torreon vs Durango (2005)
baseline_groups.outcome_concept: Child health outcomes (parasite count, diarrhea, anemia, height-for-age, weight-for-height)
baseline_groups.target_population: Children 0-5 in poor neighborhoods of Torreon and Durango (N varies: 3094-4035)
baseline_groups.expected_sign: negative for parasites/diarrhea/anemia; positive for growth measures (S_haz, S_whz)
baseline_groups.expected_sign_rationale: Cement floors reduce parasite exposure and diarrheal disease; expected to improve nutrition and growth.
baseline_groups.notes: Five baseline outcomes: S_parcount (primary, significant p=0.044), S_diarrhea (p=0.054, marginal), S_anemia (p=0.003, significant), S_haz (p=0.870, not significant), S_whz (p=0.948, not significant). rc/controls/sets runs across all 5 outcomes. rc/controls/loo and rc/sample applied to S_parcount and S_diarrhea. N varies across outcomes due to child-level data with varying measurement availability. rc/controls/loo/drop_S_age and drop_S_gender produce same coefficient as model4; plausible given balanced randomization and marginal significance of these controls.
